overview: How to boost your State Pension with National Insurance credits or voluntary payments
title: Boost your State Pension

table.body:
You might need to boost your State Pension if there are gaps in your National Insurance contributions record. This is because your National Insurance contributions count towards your State Pension. 

You can get gaps in your record if you've been:

- unemployed
- not been earning enough to pay National Insurance
- living abroad or self-employed and not paying National Insurance

To make up for this you can get credits or top up  with voluntary payments.

##National Insurance credits

With credits you carry on building up your State Pension entitlement. You can get credits automatically but sometimes you have to apply to get them. 

##Topping up your National Insurance

You can top up your National Insurance contributions with one-off voluntary payments. If you're not working or eligible for National Insurance credits you can also make regular voluntary payments.
table.title: Overview

table.body:
All types of National Insurance credits boost your basic State Pension and some boost the additional State Pension too. 

##Your age

If you were aged 16 to 18 before 6 April 2010:

- you will have been automatically credited with National Insurance contributions
- you don't need to do anything

##If you're in full-time training

If you're over 18 and in full-time training you'll get credits, provided:

- it's an approved training course 
- it doesn't last more than a year

If you're on a government-sponsored course, you don't need to do anything to get the credits. Otherwise, you need to apply.

##Parents and carers

You can get credits if you're:

- getting Child Benefit for a child under 12
- a registered foster carer
- caring for someone who's sick or disabled for at least 20 hours a week

These credits build up basic and additional State Pension. You don't need to do anything if you're already claiming:

- Carer's Allowance
- Child Benefit for a child under 12
- Income Support 

Otherwise, you need to apply.

From the 2011-12 tax year there are new credits for people aged 16 and over who care for a child under 12. You can apply after the end of the tax year - more information will be available before April 2012.

##Jobseekers

If you're unemployed and looking for work you'll automatically get credits provided you're:

- claiming Jobseeker's Allowance
- not in education or doing paid work for 16 hours a week or more


##People who are ill, disabled or on maternity leave

You can get credits if you're claiming one of the following:

- Incapacity Benefit/Employment and Support Allowance
- Maternity Allowance
- Statutory Sick Pay
- Unemployability Supplement or Allowance

This boosts your basic State Pension, but if you can't work for more than a year because of illness or disability you can also get credits towards additional State Pension. 

##Working Tax Credit

You'll get credits if you're claiming Working Tax Credit - including if you're self-employed with a Small Earnings Exception (you can apply for this if you earn less than £5,315 a year).

^If you're self-employed, there's more information on tax and National Insurance in the [guide to becoming self-employed](/become-self-employed "guide to becoming self-employed").^

##Partners of members of Her Majesty's forces

If you're married to or a civil partner of someone in the Her Majesty's forces, you can get credits if you accompany them on an overseas assignment. 

$D

[Download National Insurance credits leaflet for partners of people in the Armed Forces (PDF, 80KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@over50/documents/digitalasset/dg_187128.pdf "Download National Insurance credits leaflet for partners of people in the Armed Forces (PDF, 80K)"){:rel="external"}

$D


You can also get credits if you're on jury service or wrongly imprisoned. For more information on eligibility, call:

$C
**National Insurance Helpline**

**Telephone:** 0845 302 1479  
**Textphone:** 0845 915 3296

$C

[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: National Insurance credits - eligibility

table.body:
If you think you should be getting National Insurance credits, you can call the National Insurance Helpline:

$C
**National Insurance Helpline**

**Telephone:** 0845 302 1479  
**Textphone:** 0845 915 3296

$C

If you're caring for a child, you can apply using form CF411A - there are guidance notes to help you.


$D

table.title: How to get National Insurance credits

table.body:
There are different ways to find out if you have any gaps:

- you might get a letter from Her Majesty's Revenue & Customs (HMRC) telling you there's a gap and how much you can pay to cover it
- you can check yourself by getting a [State Pension forecast online](https://secure.thepensionservice.gov.uk/statepensionforecast/ "State Pension forecast online"){:rel="external"} 
- you can call the National Insurance Helpline:

$C
**National Insurance Helpline**

**Telephone:** 0845 302 1479  
**Textphone:** 0845 915 3296

$C



*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Find out if there are gaps in your record

table.body:
Voluntary National Insurance contributions are called 'Class 3' contributions. They boost your state pension if you're not eligible for National Insurance credits.

You can make voluntary payments to cover a National Insurance shortfall from a previous year or for the current tax year. 

##If you're self employed or live abroad

You can pay 'Class 2' contributions instead. There's extra information to help you:

- [paying self-employed National Insurance](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/payinghmrc/class2nics.htm "paying self-employed National Insurance"){:rel="external"} 
- [paying voluntary National Insurance from abroad](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/ni/volcontr/abroad.htm "paying voluntary National Insurance from abroad"){:rel="external"} 

[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Voluntary National Insurance contributions

table.body:
There's a time limit of 6 years to top up your National Insurance if there are gaps in your payment record.

Tax year with gap | Deadline for Voluntary Class 3 contributions 
- | -
2005-06 | 5 April 2012
2006-07 | 5 April 2013
2007-08 | 5 April 2014
2008-09 | 5 April 2015
2009-10 | 5 April 2016
2010-11 | 5 April 2017

If you pay more than two years after the end of the relevant tax year, the rate will normally go up to the current rate. There are some exceptions, listed below.

##Tax year 2005-06
 
You can pay voluntary Class 3 or Class 2 contributions at the weekly rates of £2.10 (Class 2) or £7.35 (Class 3) per week if you:

- reach State Pension age on or after 6 April 2010
- pay by 5 April 2012

##Tax year 2006-07

You can pay voluntary Class 3 or Class 2 contributions at the weekly rates of £2.10 (Class 2) or £7.55 (Class 3) if you:

- reach State Pension age on or after 6 April 2010
- are entitled to National Insurance credits for parents and carers
- pay by 5 April 2013

##Tax years 1993-94 to 2007-08

You can pay at the original rates if you:

- were wrongly awarded National Insurance credits
- pay by 5 April 2014

If you're not sure how much you need to pay there are historical rates tables to help.

$D

[Download National Insurance rates from 1999-2012 (PDF, 18K)](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/stats/tax_structure/table-4.pdf "Download National Insurance rates from 1999-2012 (PDF, 18KB)"){:rel="external"}

$D

$D

[Download National Insurance rates from 1993-1999 (PDF, 18K)](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/stats/tax_structure/table-a4a.pdf "Download National Insurance rates from 1993-1999 (PDF, 18KB)"){:rel="external"}

$D

##Topping up extra years

You can increase your State Pension if you reach State Pension age between 6 April 2008 and 5 April 2015:

- you can pay contributions for up to an extra 6 years - going back to 1975-76 - to make up any gaps 
- you can do this as well as making contributions for the last 6 years or any of the years with extended time limits listed above
- you pay at the current weekly rate of £12.60
- you've got 6 years from the date you reach State Pension age to pay

$D

[Download 'How to increase your State Pension if you reached State Pension age between 6 April 2008 and 5 April 2010' (PDF, 71KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@shared/documents/digitalasset/dg_180385.pdf "Download 'How to increase your State Pension if you reached State Pension age between 6 April 2008 and 5 April 2010' (PDF, 71KB)"){:rel="external"}

$D

$D

[Download 'How to increase your State Pension if you reach State Pension age between 6 April 2010 and 5 April 2015' (PDF, 71KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@shared/documents/digitalasset/dg_180387.pdf "Download 'How to increase your State Pension if you reach State Pension age between 6 April 2010 and 5 April 2015' (PDF, 71KB)"){:rel="external"}

$D
table.title: When to top up National Insurance gaps

table.body:
##Payments for the current tax year

The rates for 2011-12 are:

- £12.60 a week for Class 3 voluntary contributions
- £2.50 a week for Class 2 contributions

You can pay in two ways:

- monthly direct debit
- quarterly, using any of the methods below 


##Payments for previous years - shortfalls

You can pay in any of these ways:

- your bank (including overseas bank account) or building society's internet or telephone banking service
- Bank Giro, if your bank offers this service
- cheque, cash or debit card at a Post Office
- sending a cheque through the post

[Payment instructions for voluntary contributions](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/payinghmrc/class3nics.htm "payment instructions for voluntary contributions"){:rel="external"} are on the HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) website. They explain how to pay by any of the above methods. 

There's also information on [how to pay Class 2 National Insurance](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/payinghmrc/class2nics.htm "how to pay Class 2 National Insurance"){:rel="external"} if you're self-employed.

^If you live abroad, there's detailed [information about paying voluntary National Insurance from abroad](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/ni/volcontr/abroad.htm "information about paying voluntary National Insurance from abroad"){:rel="external"} to help you.^

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
